request_pathways.name: Authorization for Use and Disclosure of Health Information

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use a general-purpose HIPAA authorization form, checking 'Me' as recipient and 'Patient Request' as purpose, then submit via fax, mail, or email.

red_flags: 120-day authorization expiration applied to patient self-access requests, conflating time-limited third-party authorization with the patient's ongoing right of access under HIPAA § 164.524
bright_spots: EHI Export explicitly offered as a format option with detailed explanation covering all ePHI across the organization and named Community Connect Partners
Dedicated 2-page plain-language companion instruction document walks patients through each form section
Seven format options (Paper, MyChart, EHI Export, Email, Fax, CD, USB) and six delivery methods including encrypted and unencrypted email with risk warning
Help phone number provided for patients who need assistance completing the form

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available with minimal effort — forms were immediately found via simple web search and directly downloadable with no login, bot blocking, or multi-click navigation required.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds and fax/email submission available — the form has a text layer but zero fillable fields, requiring print-and-handwrite then fax or scan-and-email to submit.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — logical section flow, clear headers, reasonable 2-page length, and a companion instruction document in plain language, though some regulatory terminology in the EHI and rights sections.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic HIPAA authorization form serves all purposes, and patients must determine which fields apply to self-access vs. third-party release, though the 'Me' checkbox and instruction document help.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but nothing materially impeding — no notarization, multiple submission channels, solid rights statement, but the 120-day expiration unnecessarily applied to patient self-access and no fee transparency.

overall.summary: Owensboro Health earns a B through excellent findability, comprehensive format/delivery options, and a rare EHI Export offering, limited by a non-fillable form and lack of a dedicated patient access pathway.
